messageBody:
> Here I would like to ask a question... Do you think it would be a
desirable
> design decision to refactor your class(es) to reflect the first method of
> testing? That is have a base class that handles TCP/IP traffic requests
and
> then two decendents (one that tunnels through SSL and one that doesn't).

First of all, thank you Johannes and Jason for your replies to my
question. This has gotten me to thinking, and is becoming even more
interesting. Specifically, it is very interesting how thinking about
testing affects the design of the product code.

In my particular case it is already true that (virtually) all of the
code I'm trying to test doesn't care whether we're using SSL or not.
The beauty of these SSL libraries is precisely that they allow you to
treat a socket as a socket, whether or not it has SSL going on under
the covers.

So, in a way, that suggests that if all I want to test is my code,
then I shouldn't have to test the same thing twice. All I (should)
want to do is to verify that my code produces the results I think it
should, given a certain input. That would be true Unit Testing.

Now I had a number of problems recently that I traced not to failure
of my code to do what I thought it should do, but rather to
discrepancies between the behavior of plain sockets and SSL sockets.
In other words, the SSL libraries had bugs in them. (For example, one
problem concerned how the server should protect itself from an I/O
operation that takes an "impossibly" long duration.)

So then I thought maybe what I'm trying to do here isn't really Unit
Testing. Because I'm trying to test the operation of the system as a
whole (or at least a part of it that is bigger than one "unit"). So
what is it? Is it "Functional Testing"? I don't think so, because
this unusual error case isn't something that I would expect I could
find in a collection of User Stories.

In retrospect, I can come up with a characterization of the problem
and say that I made certain assumptions about the behavior of the
sockets API. Given that was the case, it would have been prudent of
me to write (very simple) test cases that verify those assumptions,
and run them on both plain and SSL sockets. These tests, of course,
would be very simple, and wouldn't involve any of my product code.

Presumably if I tested the assumptions correctly in both cases, then I
wouldn't have to test my code in both of its configurations (since
from its point of view it's not really doing anything different in the
two different cases).

Is this another form of testing ("Assumption Testing")? Or perhaps
another way to look at it is that I'm a "customer" of the SSL library
provider, and I need to have my own "Acceptance Test" of the
functionality that I expect it to provide?

And, even if I try to persuade myself that this would be the correct
way to test, somehow I'm nervous that I would miss a test case, or not
be aware of some assumption that I had made.

- Alan Bram
